results.title: Heidi
results.brief_description: Heidi, a high spirited Swiss orphan, is taken to live with her grandfather in the Swiss Alps where she lives in harmony with her surroundings and becomes friends with Peter, a young goatherd. Her Aunt arrives unexpectedly and forces her to leave the mountains and the grandfather she adores. She is taken to live with a city family and although she becomes close to Clara, her young companion who is doomed to spend her life in a wheelchair, Heidi is terribly homesick and wonders if she will ever return to the mountains to see her grandfather again.

results.title: Hector goes to play ball
results.creator_credit: Phillip Mark-Law, Lindsay Parker and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: A fantasy which employs fun-loving Hector the Cat to teach children road safety rules. Hector is a giant cat who lives in the botanical gardens and loves to play with the children who visit him there. He leads them in an assortment of colourful games, but comes to a bad end because he forgets his road safety rules.

results.title: Hector and Milly save Uncle Tom
results.brief_description: Hector has just married Milly, and before they drive off, he checks his bride’s safety belt. Their first house guest is Uncle Tom, a silly old man lacking all road sense. It takes all Hector and Milly’s time saving him from trouble. Words and music by Charles Marawood, Damien Parer - Unit Manager. Costumed characters performed in pantomime musical style.

results.title: Heavy horse pull
results.creator_credit: Roberta King, Ronald Squire, Beryl Fox, Don Hopkins and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A humorous documentary about horse-pulling contests in Ontario and the people who prepare for them, this film tackles heavy loads with a light touch. It travels from the farm to the contest, where excitement runs high and the quips do not lack in local colour. Photographed by Robert Fresco.

results.title: Heathlands
results.brief_description: The first section studies the geology of the dry, sandy heathlands typical of south-eastern England and part of northern France. The second section introduces flora typical of the uncultivated heathlands and the final section deals with the fauna of the heathlands.

results.title: Heather Locklear chocolate
results.brief_description: Award-winning comedy about a gender-bending teenager (Einar Johansen) and his passion for nail polish. Each of his favorites has a story behind it, however his ‘holy grail’ of nail polishes is a colour worn by Heather Locklear in ‘Melrose Place’.

Episode number 3 of Series “Structure and Properties of Steel”.

results.title: Heat causes expansion
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description: Shows two children carrying out experiments in their home to prove that solids, liquids and gases expand when heated. Also shows many ways in which this law of physics occurs in everyday life. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Hearts in paradise
results.creator_credit: Judith Hewitson and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The lifestyle of Jo, a new wave singer, is compared and contrasted with Teresa, a would-be mothercraft worker. This is viewed against the background of society’s general resistance and non-comprehension of that which is new and different.

results.title: Heartlands: diversity or dust
results.brief_description: Narrated by Richard Bawden this episode looks at a small group of farmers who have developed a meaningful relationship with the land. When these farmers arrived on their selections in Western Australia in the fifties, they were required by the Lands Department to clear a certain percentage of their land. Initially, believing that opening up the land and growing wheat was a worthy enterprise, they readily cleared the native bush. As time went on some of them realised that this practice was doing great damage, increasing salinity and rendering the land barren. Gradually they developed an understanding of the balance of the natural environment, and realised that the ‘empty’ land they had settled contained plant species of enormous diversity. Led by Veronica Kingdon, the farmers conducted and won a campaign against the Lands Department. Their political lobbying has stopped all major land clearing in the state. Their efforts also contributed to the establishment of Fitzgerald National Park, one of the richest botanical regions in the world. Now self-taught botanists, geologists, nature photographers and seed collectors they conduct a wildflower show each year to raise awareness about plant diversity in the region. Their efforts are a model for showing how a small group of dedicated individuals can bring about profound change.
